case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. First Respondent and Second Respondent

facts.text: This appeal by special leave is against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay rejecting in limine the criminal revision filed by the appellant

facts.text: Magistrate framed charges against second respondent under sections 381 and 385 IPC

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse, the Magistrate framed charges against the second respondent under the said sections. Pending the trial, the first respondent applied to the Magistrate to summon the income-tax authorities to produce certain letters alleged to have been written by the second respondent to the said authorities making baseless allegations against the first respondent. On March 27, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax wrote a letter to the Magistrate admitting that some letters written by the second respondent were with the income-tax department, but pleaded that they companyld number be produced in view of the provisions of section 54 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Pending trial first respondent applied to Magistrate to summon income-tax authorities to produce letters written by second respondent

anchor.surface_text: Pending the trial, the first respondent applied to the Magistrate to summon the income-tax authorities to produce certain letters alleged to have been written by the second respondent to the said authorities making baseless allegations against the first respondent. On March 27, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax wrote a letter to the Magistrate admitting that some letters written by the second respondent were with the income-tax department, but pleaded that they companyld number be produced in view of the provisions of section 54 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The Presidency Magistrate, by his order dated May 16, 1958, overruled his objections and directed the Commissioner of Income-tax to produce the documents admitted to be in his possession or in the possession officers subordinate to him.

facts.text: On March 27 1958 Commissioner of Income-tax wrote letter to Magistrate admitting letters by second respondent with department but cannot produce per section 54 Income-tax Act 1922

anchor.surface_text: On March 27, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax wrote a letter to the Magistrate admitting that some letters written by the second respondent were with the income-tax department, but pleaded that they companyld number be produced in view of the provisions of section 54 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The Presidency Magistrate, by his order dated May 16, 1958, overruled his objections and directed the Commissioner of Income-tax to produce the documents admitted to be in his possession or in the possession officers subordinate to him. The Commissioner of Income-tax preferred and appeal against the order to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, but the some was rejected.

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate by order dated May 16 1958 overruled objections and directed Commissioner to produce documents

arguments.claim: Section 54 is in two parts: first declares particulars in assessment records confidential; second debars courts from requiring production by public servants, save as provided in the Act; subsections prohibit disclosure in court

anchor.surface_text: The section is in two parts the first part declares that all particulars companytained in the documents described therein shall be treated as companyfidential, and the second part, save as provided in the Act, debars the companyrt from requiring any public servant to produce in companyrt the said documents. Sub-section  2  makes the disclosure of the companytents of the said documents by a public servant an offence.

arguments.claim: the non obstante clause in section 54 only operates to make it clear that the general ban prevails notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the Indian Evidence Act; prohibition is unconditional and does not exclude criminal process

anchor.surface_text: The number obstante clause cannot restrict the embargo placed on the companyrt under section 54 of the Income-tax Act the said clause only operates to make it clear that the said general ban prevails numberwithstanding anything to the companytrary in the Indian Evidence Act. That apart, section 54 of the Income-tax Act companytains in effect an unconditional prohibition against a public servant producing any such document, and that prohibition does number exclude any criminal process from its operation.

holdings.text: No court shall be entitled to require any public servant to produce before it any record of any assessment proceeding or any part thereof under section 54 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, where the documents form part of the record of an assessment proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: The Presidency Magistrate held that the documents in question formed part of the record of the assessment proceeding and nothing has been placed before us to displace the said finding. We shall, therefore, proceed on the basis that the condition laid down in the first part of section 54 of the Income-tax Act has been complied with. On the said basis, this appeal is covered by the decision of this court in Charu Chandra Kundu v. Gurupada Ghosh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents confirmed as part of assessment record by lower court finding not displaced; directly covered by prior Supreme Court precedent applying s.54 prohibition.

holdings.text: The prohibition under section 54 of the Income-tax Act applies to documents forming part of assessment records even if produced by third parties and not only by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: But learned counsel for the respondents seeks to distinguish that case on the ground that in the present case the letters sought to be produced were sent to the department by a third party and not by the assessee. But even in the earlier decision of this court the documents sought to be produced were not the documents filed by the assessee but only a statement made by a third party, who was the respondent in the case. The attempted distinction of that case from the present one has neither a legal nor a factual basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent case also involved third-party statement in assessment records, not assessee documents; no basis to distinguish.

holdings.text: The prohibition in section 54 of the Income-tax Act overrides the power of a criminal court under section 94 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to summon such documents.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we accept the argument of learned counsel that the order directing the production of the documents was made under section 94 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and that that section is not hit by the prohibition under section 54 of the Income-tax Act. This argument is advanced on the basis that the non obstante clause in sub-section (1) of section 54 of the Income-tax Act only relates to the Indian Evidence Act and not to the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.54 contains unconditional prohibition on production; prevails over procedural powers in CrPC.

holdings.text: The non obstante clause in section 54(1) of the Income-tax Act operates to ensure the general ban prevails notwithstanding the Indian Evidence Act, but the prohibition is not limited to the Evidence Act and applies generally including to CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The non obstante clause cannot restrict the embargo placed on the court under section 54 of the Income-tax Act the said clause only operates to make it clear that the said general ban prevails notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the Indian Evidence Act. That apart, section 54 of the Income-tax Act contains in effect an unconditional prohibition against a public servant producing any such document, and that prohibition does not exclude any criminal process from its operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause clarifies override of Evidence Act; s.54 prohibition unconditional and applies to all courts/processes.

holdings.text: There are no merits in the respondents' contentions; the objections raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax against production of the documents are sustained.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that there are no merits in this contention either. In the result, we sustain the objections raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax against the production of the said documents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of all respondent arguments based on textual interpretation of s.54, precedent, and unconditional nature of prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The Presidency Magistrate held that the documents in question formed part of the record of the assessment proceeding and nothing has been placed before us to displace the said finding. We shall, therefore, proceed on the basis that the condition laid down in the first part of section 54 of the Income-tax Act has been complied with. On the said basis, this appeal is covered by the decision of this court in Charu Chandra Kundu v. Gurupada Ghosh.
In the result, we sustain the objections raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax against the production of the said documents.
v. Gurupada Ghosh. There, in a suit filed by the respondent for recovery of money, the appellate applied to the companyrt for the issue of a summons a

edges.explanation: h2 addresses i2 scope to third parties

anchor.surface_text: But learned counsel for the respondents seeks to distinguish that case on the ground that in the present case the letters sought to be produced were sent to the department by a third party and not by the assessee. But even in the earlier decision of this court the documents sought to be produced were not the documents filed by the assessee but only a statement made by a third party, who was the respondent in the case. The attempted distinction of that case from the present one has neither a legal nor a factual basis.
In the result, we sustain the objections raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax against the production of the said documents.
shable with imprisonment which may extend to six months, and shall also be liable to fine. The section is in two parts the first part declares that al

edges.explanation: h3 addresses i3 override of CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we accept the argument of learned counsel that the order directing the production of the documents was made under section 94 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and that that section is not hit by the prohibition under section 54 of the Income-tax Act. This argument is advanced on the basis that the non obstante clause in sub-section (1) of section 54 of the Income-tax Act only relates to the Indian Evidence Act and not to the Code of Criminal Procedure.
In the result, we sustain the objections raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax against the production of the said documents.

edges.explanation: Holding explains the operation of the non obstante clause notwithstanding the Indian Evidence Act, directly addressing the issue of its scope relative to the Evidence Act and CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The non obstante clause cannot restrict the embargo placed on the court under section 54 of the Income-tax Act the said clause only operates to make it clear that the said general ban prevails notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the Indian Evidence Act. That apart, section 54 of the Income-tax Act contains in effect an unconditional prohibition against a public servant producing any such document, and that prohibition does not exclude any criminal process from its operation.
In the result, we sustain the objections raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax against the production of the said documents.
